\section{The stable motivic homotopy category}

We first sketch a construction of the stable motivic homotopy category
that will be convenient for our purposes, and in the process, set our
notation.  Treatments of stable motivic homotopy theory can be found
in \cite{Ayoub2,MotFunctors,Nordfjordeid,Jardine,SMod}.

\subsection{Base schemes}

A base scheme $B$ is a Noetherian separated scheme of finite Krull
dimension.  We write ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$ for the category of smooth schemes of
finite type over $B$.  Let ${\mathrm{Pshv}}({\mathrm{Sm}}/B)$ denote the category of
presheaves of sets on ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  A space over $B$ is a simplicial
presheaf on ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  The collection of spaces over $B$ forms the
category ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B) = \Delta^{op} {\mathrm{Pshv}}({\mathrm{Sm}}/B)$, where morphisms are
natural transformations of functors.  We write ${\mathrm{Spc}}_{*}(B)$ for the
category of pointed spaces.  Note that ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ is naturally
equivalent to the category of presheaves on ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$ with values in the
category of simplicial sets ${\operatorname{\underline{sSet}}}$.  We will occasionally switch
between the two perspectives.

\subsection{The projective model structure}

The first model category structure we endow ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ with is the
projective model structure, see, e.g., \cite[Thm.\,1.4]{Blander},
\cite[Thm.\,2.7]{MotFunctors}, \cite[Thm.\,11.6.1]{Hhorn}.

\begin{definition}
  A map $f : X \to Y$ in ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ is a (global) weak equivalence if
  for any $U \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$ the map $f(U): X(U) \to Y(U)$ of simplicial
  sets is a weak equivalence.  The projective fibrations are those
  maps $f :X \to Y$ for which $f(U) : X(U) \to Y(U)$ is a Kan
  fibration for any $U \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  The projective cofibrations are
  those maps in ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ which satisfy the left lifting property for
  trivial projective fibrations.  This defines the projective model
  structure on ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$.
\end{definition}

The category ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ equipped with the projective structure is
cellular, proper, and simplicial \cite[Thm.\,1.4]{Blander}.
Furthermore, ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ has the structure of a simplicial monoidal
model category, with product $\times$ and internal hom
$\underline{{\operatorname{Hom}}}$.  We write ${\mathrm{Map}}({\mathcal{X}}, {\mathcal{Y}})$ for the simplicial
mapping space for spaces ${\mathcal{X}}$ and ${\mathcal{Y}}$.

\begin{definition}
  For a smooth scheme $X$ over $B$, we write $rX$ for the
  representable presheaf of simplicial sets.  For $U \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$, the
  simplicial set $rX(U)$ is given by $rX(U)_n = {\mathrm{Sm}}/B(U,X)$ for all $n
  \in \Delta$ where the face and degeneracy maps are the identity map.
  We will occasionally abuse notation and write $X$ for $rX$.

  The constant presheaf functor $c : {\operatorname{\underline{sSet}}} \to {\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ associates to
  a simplicial set $A$ the presheaf $cA$ defined by $cA(U) = A$ for
  any $U \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.
\end{definition}

The functor $c$ is a left Quillen functor when ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ is equipped
with the projective model structure.  Its right adjoint ${\mathrm{Ev}}_B :
{\mathrm{Spc}}(B) \to {\operatorname{\underline{sSet}}}$ satisfies ${\mathrm{Ev}}_B(X) = X(B)$.  One can show that
representable presheaves and constant presheaves in ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ are
cofibrant with the projective model structure.


\subsection{The Nisnevich local model structure}

Although representable presheaves embed into ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$, colimits which
exist in ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$ are not necessarily preserved in ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$.  That is,
if $X = {\operatorname{colim}} X_i$ in ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$, it need not be true that
$rX = {\operatorname{colim}} rX_i$, e.g.,
${\operatorname{colim}} (r{\mathbb{A}}^1 \leftarrow r{\mathbb{G}}_m \to r{\mathbb{A}}^1) \neq r{\mathbb{P}}^1$ (as one
can check by applying the Picard group functor).  To fix this, one
introduces the Nisnevich topology on ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.

\begin{definition}[Nisnevich topology] 
  Let $B$ be a base scheme.  For any $X \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$, let
  ${\mathcal{U}} = \{ U_i \to X \}$ be a finite family of \'etale maps in
  ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  We say ${\mathcal{U}}$ is a Nisnevich covering of $X$ if for any
  $x\in X$ there exists a map $U_i \to X \in {\mathcal{U}}$ and a point
  $u\in U_i$ for which the induced map of residue fields
  $k(x) \to k(u)$ is an isomorphism.  The Nisnevich covers determine a
  Grothendieck topology on ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Elementary distinguished squares]

  An elementary distinguished square is a diagram in ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$

for which $f$ is an {\'e}tale map, $j$ is an open embedding, and
  $f^{-1}(X-V) \to X-V$ is an isomorphism, where these subschemes are
  given the reduced structure.
\end{definition}

\begin{proposition} 
  The Nisnevich topology is the smallest topology containing the
  covers $\{V \to X,X'\to X\}$ which come from an elementary
  distinguished square.
\end{proposition}

\begin{definition} 
  For a pointed space ${\mathcal{X}}$, and $n\geq 0$, let $\pi_n{\mathcal{X}}$ denote
  the Nisnevich sheafification of the presheaf
  $U \mapsto \pi_n({\mathcal{X}}(U))$.

  Let $W_{Nis}$ denote the class of maps $f : {\mathcal{X}} \to {\mathcal{Y}}$ for
  which $f_* : \pi_n {\mathcal{X}} \to \pi_n {\mathcal{Y}}$ is an isomorphism of
  Nisnevich sheaves for all $n \geq 0$.  The Nisnevich local model
  structure on ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$ is the left Bousfield localization of the
  projective model structure with respect to $W_{Nis}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}
  \label{motivic_model_cat} 
  Let $W_{{\mathbb{A}}^1}$ be the class of maps
  $\pi_{X}: (X \times {\mathbb{A}}^1)_+ \to X_+$ for $X \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  The
  motivic model structure on ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$ is the left Bousfield
  localization of the projective model structure with respect to
  $W_{Nis} \cup W_{{\mathbb{A}}^1}$.  We write ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$ for the
  category of pointed spaces equipped with the motivic model
  structure.  The pointed motivic homotopy category
  ${\mathcal{H}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$ is the homotopy category of
  ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$.  Compare with \cite[p.\,5]{HKOst}.  For
  pointed spaces $X$ and $Y$, we write $[X,Y]$ for the set of maps
  ${\mathcal{H}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)(X,Y)$.
\end{definition}

There are two circles in the category of pointed spaces: the constant
simplicial presheaf $S^1$ pointed at its $0$-simplex and the
representable presheaf ${\mathbb{G}}_m = {\mathbb{A}}^1 \setminus \{0\}$ pointed at
$1$.  These determine a bi-graded family of spheres
$S^{p,q} = (S^1)^{\wedge p-q}\wedge {\mathbb{G}}_m^{\wedge q}$.

\begin{definition} 
  For a pointed space $X$ over $B$ and natural numbers $i$ and $j$,
  let $\pi_{i,j}X$ denote the set of maps $[S^{i,j},X]$.
\end{definition}

The category of pointed spaces ${\mathrm{Spc}}_{*}(B)$ equipped with the induced
motivic model category structure has many good properties which make
it amenable to Bousfield localization.  In particular, ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$ is
closed symmetric monoidal, pointed simplicial, left proper, and
cellular.



\subsection{The stable Nisnevich local model structure}

With the unstable motivic model category in hand, we now construct the
stable motivic model category using the general framework laid out in
\cite{H-Spectra}.

Let $T$ be a cofibrant replacement of ${\mathbb{A}}^1/{\mathbb{A}}^1-\{0\}$.  One can
show that $T$ is weak equivalent to $S^{2,1}$ in
${\mathrm{Spc}}_{*}^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$.  The functor $T \wedge -$ on
${\mathrm{Spc}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$ is a left Quillen functor, which we may invert by
creating a category of $T$-spectra.

\begin{definition}
  \label{T-spectra} 
  A $T$-spectrum is a sequence of spaces $X_n \in {\mathrm{Spc}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$
  equipped with structure maps $\sigma_n : T \wedge X_n \to X_{n+1}$.
  A map of $T$-spectra $f: X \to Y$ is a collection of maps
  $f_n : X_n \to Y_n$ which is compatible with the structure maps.  We
  write ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$ for the category of $T$-spectra of spaces.

  The level model structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$ is given by declaring a map
  $f : X \to Y$ to be a cofibration (resp. weak equivalence,
  fibration) if for every map $f_n :X_n \to Y_n$ is a cofibration
  (resp. weak equivalence, fibration) in the motivic model structure
  on ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition} 
  Let $X$ be a $T$-spectrum.  For integers $i$ and $j$, the $(i,j)$
  stable homotopy sheaf of $X$ is the sheaf
  $\pi_{i,j}X = {\operatorname{colim}}_n \pi_{i+2n,j+n}X_n$.
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  A map $f:X \to Y$ is a stable weak equivalence if for all integers
  $i$ and $j$, the induced maps $f_* : \pi_{i,j}X \to \pi_{i,j}Y$ are
  isomorphisms.
\end{definition}
  
\begin{definition} 
  The stable model structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$ is the model category
  where the weak equivalences are the stable weak equivalences and the
  cofibrations are the cofibrations in the level model structure.  The
  fibrations are those maps with the right lifting property with
  respect to trivial cofibrations.  We write ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ for the homotopy
  category of ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$ equipped with the stable model structure.
\end{definition}

The stable model structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$ can be realized as a left
Bousfield localization of the level-wise model structure
\cite[Def.\,3.3]{H-Spectra}.

Just as for the category ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}$ of simplicial $S^1$-spectra,
there isn't a symmetric monoidal category structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$
which lifts the smash product $\wedge$ in ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$.  One remedy is to
use a category of symmetric $T$-spectra ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T^{\Sigma}(B)$.  The
construction of this category is given in \cite[Def.\,7.7]{H-Spectra},
\cite{Jardine}.  By \cite[Thm.\,9.1]{H-Spectra}, there is a zig-zag of
Quillen equivalences from ${\mathrm{Spt}}^{\Sigma}_T(B)$ to ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$, so ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$
is equivalent to the homotopy category of ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T^{\Sigma}(B)$ as
well.  The category ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ therefore is a symmetric monoidal,
triangulated category, where the shift functor is given by
$[1] = S^{1,0}\wedge -$.

In addition to the category of $T$-spectra, we will find it convenient
to work with the category of $({\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1)$ bi-spectra, see
\cite{Jardine, Nordfjordeid}.

\begin{definition} 
  An $S^1$-spectrum over the base scheme $B$ is a sequence of spaces
  $X_n \in {\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$ equipped with structure maps
  $\sigma_n : S^1 \wedge X_n \to X_{n+1}$.  A map of $S^1$-spectra
  $f : X \to Y$ is a sequence of maps $f_n :X_n \to Y_n$ which is
  compatible with the structure maps.  The collection of $S^1$-spectra
  with compatible maps between them forms a category ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B)$.
  Similar to the construction in definition \ref{T-spectra}, the
  stable model structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B)$ is the left Bousfield
  localization of the level model structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B)$ with
  respect to the motivic model structure on ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$ at the stable
  equivalences, cf.~\cite[Def.\,3.3]{H-Spectra}.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition} 
  In the projective model structure on ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$, the space ${\mathbb{G}}_m$
  pointed at $1$ is not cofibrant.  We abuse notation, and write
  ${\mathbb{G}}_m$ for a cofibrant replacement of ${\mathbb{G}}_m$.  A $({\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1)$
  bi-spectrum over $B$ is a ${\mathbb{G}}_m$-spectrum of $S^1$-spectra.  More
  concretely, a $({\mathbb{G}}_m,S^1)$ bi-spectrum $E$ is a bi-graded family
  of spaces $E_{m,n}$ with bonding maps
  $\sigma_{m,n} : S^1 \wedge E_{m,n} \to E_{m,n+1}$ and
  $\gamma_{m,n} : {\mathbb{G}}_m \wedge E_{m,n} \to E_{m+1,n}$ which are
  compatible, meaning that the following diagram commutes.

\section{The stable motivic homotopy category}

We first sketch a construction of the stable motivic homotopy category
that will be convenient for our purposes, and in the process, set our
notation.  Treatments of stable motivic homotopy theory can be found
in \cite{Ayoub2,MotFunctors,Nordfjordeid,Jardine,SMod}.

\subsection{Base schemes}

A base scheme $B$ is a Noetherian separated scheme of finite Krull
dimension.  We write ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$ for the category of smooth schemes of
finite type over $B$.  Let ${\mathrm{Pshv}}({\mathrm{Sm}}/B)$ denote the category of
presheaves of sets on ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  A space over $B$ is a simplicial
presheaf on ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  The collection of spaces over $B$ forms the
category ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B) = \Delta^{op} {\mathrm{Pshv}}({\mathrm{Sm}}/B)$, where morphisms are
natural transformations of functors.  We write ${\mathrm{Spc}}_{*}(B)$ for the
category of pointed spaces.  Note that ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ is naturally
equivalent to the category of presheaves on ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$ with values in the
category of simplicial sets ${\operatorname{\underline{sSet}}}$.  We will occasionally switch
between the two perspectives.

\subsection{The projective model structure}

The first model category structure we endow ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ with is the
projective model structure, see, e.g., \cite[Thm.\,1.4]{Blander},
\cite[Thm.\,2.7]{MotFunctors}, \cite[Thm.\,11.6.1]{Hhorn}.

\begin{definition}
  A map $f : X \to Y$ in ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ is a (global) weak equivalence if
  for any $U \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$ the map $f(U): X(U) \to Y(U)$ of simplicial
  sets is a weak equivalence.  The projective fibrations are those
  maps $f :X \to Y$ for which $f(U) : X(U) \to Y(U)$ is a Kan
  fibration for any $U \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  The projective cofibrations are
  those maps in ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ which satisfy the left lifting property for
  trivial projective fibrations.  This defines the projective model
  structure on ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$.
\end{definition}

The category ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ equipped with the projective structure is
cellular, proper, and simplicial \cite[Thm.\,1.4]{Blander}.
Furthermore, ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ has the structure of a simplicial monoidal
model category, with product $\times$ and internal hom
$\underline{{\operatorname{Hom}}}$.  We write ${\mathrm{Map}}({\mathcal{X}}, {\mathcal{Y}})$ for the simplicial
mapping space for spaces ${\mathcal{X}}$ and ${\mathcal{Y}}$.

\begin{definition}
  For a smooth scheme $X$ over $B$, we write $rX$ for the
  representable presheaf of simplicial sets.  For $U \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$, the
  simplicial set $rX(U)$ is given by $rX(U)_n = {\mathrm{Sm}}/B(U,X)$ for all $n
  \in \Delta$ where the face and degeneracy maps are the identity map.
  We will occasionally abuse notation and write $X$ for $rX$.

  The constant presheaf functor $c : {\operatorname{\underline{sSet}}} \to {\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ associates to
  a simplicial set $A$ the presheaf $cA$ defined by $cA(U) = A$ for
  any $U \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.
\end{definition}

The functor $c$ is a left Quillen functor when ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ is equipped
with the projective model structure.  Its right adjoint ${\mathrm{Ev}}_B :
{\mathrm{Spc}}(B) \to {\operatorname{\underline{sSet}}}$ satisfies ${\mathrm{Ev}}_B(X) = X(B)$.  One can show that
representable presheaves and constant presheaves in ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$ are
cofibrant with the projective model structure.


\subsection{The Nisnevich local model structure}

Although representable presheaves embed into ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$, colimits which
exist in ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$ are not necessarily preserved in ${\mathrm{Spc}}(B)$.  That is,
if $X = {\operatorname{colim}} X_i$ in ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$, it need not be true that
$rX = {\operatorname{colim}} rX_i$, e.g.,
${\operatorname{colim}} (r{\mathbb{A}}^1 \leftarrow r{\mathbb{G}}_m \to r{\mathbb{A}}^1) \neq r{\mathbb{P}}^1$ (as one
can check by applying the Picard group functor).  To fix this, one
introduces the Nisnevich topology on ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.

\begin{definition}[Nisnevich topology] 
  Let $B$ be a base scheme.  For any $X \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$, let
  ${\mathcal{U}} = \{ U_i \to X \}$ be a finite family of \'etale maps in
  ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  We say ${\mathcal{U}}$ is a Nisnevich covering of $X$ if for any
  $x\in X$ there exists a map $U_i \to X \in {\mathcal{U}}$ and a point
  $u\in U_i$ for which the induced map of residue fields
  $k(x) \to k(u)$ is an isomorphism.  The Nisnevich covers determine a
  Grothendieck topology on ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Elementary distinguished squares]

  An elementary distinguished square is a diagram in ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$

Thinking of ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1}$ as the category of ${\mathbb{G}}_m$-spectra of
$S^1$-spectra, we first equip ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1}$ with the level model category
structure with respect to the stable model category structure on
${\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B)$.  The stable model category structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1}$ is
the left Bousfield localization at the class of stable equivalences.
\end{definition}

There are evidently left Quillen functors
$\Sigma^{\infty}_{S^1} : {\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B) \to {\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B)$ and
$\Sigma^{\infty}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m} : {\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B) \to {\mathrm{Spt}}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1}(B)$.
Additionally, the category ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1}(B)$ equipped with the stable model
structure is Quillen equivalent to ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$.

\begin{definition} 
  To any spectrum of simplicial sets $E \in {\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}$ we may
  associate the constant $S^1$-spectrum $cE$ over $B$ with value $E$.
  That is, $cE$ is the sequence of spaces $cE_n$ with the evident
  bonding maps.  For a simplicial spectrum $E$, we also write $cE$ for
  the $({\mathbb{G}}_m,S^1)$ bi-spectrum $\Sigma^{\infty}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m} cE$.  This
  defines a left Quillen functor $c : {\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1} \to {\mathrm{Spt}}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1}(B)$ with
  right adjoint given by evaluation at $B$.  Compare with \cite[Lemma
  6.5]{Levine}.
\end{definition}



\subsection{Base change of stable model categories}

\begin{definition} 
  Let $f : C \to B$ be a map of base schemes.  Pull-back along $f$
  determines a functor $f^{-1} : {\mathrm{Sm}}/B \to {\mathrm{Sm}}/C$, which induces
  Quillen adjunctions
  $(f^*, f_*) : {\mathrm{Spc}}^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}_*(B) \to {\mathrm{Spc}}^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}_*(C)$ and
  $(f^*, f_*) : {\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B) \to {\mathrm{Spt}}_T(C)$.  See e.g.,
  \cite[\S5]{Morel-Con} for more details.

  Let $Q$ (resp.~$R$) denote the cofibrant (resp.~fibrant) replacement
  functor in ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$.  The derived functors ${\mathbb{L}} f^*$ and
  ${\mathbb{R}} f_*$ are given by the formulas ${\mathbb{L}} f^* = f^* Q$ and
  ${\mathbb{R}} f_* = f_* R$.
\end{definition}









\section{Comparison to the classical stable homotopy category}
We start this section by recalling \cite[Thm.\,1]{Levine}.
\begin{theorem-prop}
  \label{levine_comparison} 
  If $B = {\operatorname{Spec}}({\mathbb{C}})$, the map ${\mathbb{L}} c : {\mathcal{SH}} \to {\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ is fully
  faithful.
\end{theorem-prop}

\begin{proposition}
  \label{const_comm} 
  Let $f : C \to B$ be a map of base schemes.  The following diagram
  of stable homotopy categories commutes.

  $f^{-1}(X-V) \to X-V$ is an isomorphism, where these subschemes are

\end{definition}

\begin{proposition} 
  The Nisnevich topology is the smallest topology containing the
  covers $\{V \to X,X'\to X\}$ which come from an elementary
  distinguished square.
\end{proposition}

\begin{definition} 
  For a pointed space ${\mathcal{X}}$, and $n\geq 0$, let $\pi_n{\mathcal{X}}$ denote
  the Nisnevich sheafification of the presheaf
  $U \mapsto \pi_n({\mathcal{X}}(U))$.

  Let $W_{Nis}$ denote the class of maps $f : {\mathcal{X}} \to {\mathcal{Y}}$ for
  which $f_* : \pi_n {\mathcal{X}} \to \pi_n {\mathcal{Y}}$ is an isomorphism of
  Nisnevich sheaves for all $n \geq 0$.  The Nisnevich local model
  structure on ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$ is the left Bousfield localization of the
  projective model structure with respect to $W_{Nis}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}
  \label{motivic_model_cat} 
  Let $W_{{\mathbb{A}}^1}$ be the class of maps
  $\pi_{X}: (X \times {\mathbb{A}}^1)_+ \to X_+$ for $X \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  The
  motivic model structure on ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$ is the left Bousfield
  localization of the projective model structure with respect to
  $W_{Nis} \cup W_{{\mathbb{A}}^1}$.  We write ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$ for the
  category of pointed spaces equipped with the motivic model
  structure.  The pointed motivic homotopy category
  ${\mathcal{H}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$ is the homotopy category of
  ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$.  Compare with \cite[p.\,5]{HKOst}.  For
  pointed spaces $X$ and $Y$, we write $[X,Y]$ for the set of maps
  ${\mathcal{H}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)(X,Y)$.
\end{definition}

There are two circles in the category of pointed spaces: the constant
simplicial presheaf $S^1$ pointed at its $0$-simplex and the
representable presheaf ${\mathbb{G}}_m = {\mathbb{A}}^1 \setminus \{0\}$ pointed at
$1$.  These determine a bi-graded family of spheres
$S^{p,q} = (S^1)^{\wedge p-q}\wedge {\mathbb{G}}_m^{\wedge q}$.

\begin{definition} 
  For a pointed space $X$ over $B$ and natural numbers $i$ and $j$,
  let $\pi_{i,j}X$ denote the set of maps $[S^{i,j},X]$.
\end{definition}

The category of pointed spaces ${\mathrm{Spc}}_{*}(B)$ equipped with the induced
motivic model category structure has many good properties which make
it amenable to Bousfield localization.  In particular, ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$ is
closed symmetric monoidal, pointed simplicial, left proper, and
cellular.



\subsection{The stable Nisnevich local model structure}

With the unstable motivic model category in hand, we now construct the
stable motivic model category using the general framework laid out in
\cite{H-Spectra}.

Let $T$ be a cofibrant replacement of ${\mathbb{A}}^1/{\mathbb{A}}^1-\{0\}$.  One can
show that $T$ is weak equivalent to $S^{2,1}$ in
${\mathrm{Spc}}_{*}^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$.  The functor $T \wedge -$ on
${\mathrm{Spc}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$ is a left Quillen functor, which we may invert by
creating a category of $T$-spectra.

\begin{definition}
  \label{T-spectra} 
  A $T$-spectrum is a sequence of spaces $X_n \in {\mathrm{Spc}}_*^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}(B)$
  equipped with structure maps $\sigma_n : T \wedge X_n \to X_{n+1}$.
  A map of $T$-spectra $f: X \to Y$ is a collection of maps
  $f_n : X_n \to Y_n$ which is compatible with the structure maps.  We
  write ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$ for the category of $T$-spectra of spaces.

  The level model structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$ is given by declaring a map
  $f : X \to Y$ to be a cofibration (resp. weak equivalence,
  fibration) if for every map $f_n :X_n \to Y_n$ is a cofibration
  (resp. weak equivalence, fibration) in the motivic model structure
  on ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition} 
  Let $X$ be a $T$-spectrum.  For integers $i$ and $j$, the $(i,j)$
  stable homotopy sheaf of $X$ is the sheaf
  $\pi_{i,j}X = {\operatorname{colim}}_n \pi_{i+2n,j+n}X_n$.
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  A map $f:X \to Y$ is a stable weak equivalence if for all integers
  $i$ and $j$, the induced maps $f_* : \pi_{i,j}X \to \pi_{i,j}Y$ are
  isomorphisms.
\end{definition}
  
\begin{definition} 
  The stable model structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$ is the model category
  where the weak equivalences are the stable weak equivalences and the
  cofibrations are the cofibrations in the level model structure.  The
  fibrations are those maps with the right lifting property with
  respect to trivial cofibrations.  We write ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ for the homotopy
  category of ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$ equipped with the stable model structure.
\end{definition}

The stable model structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$ can be realized as a left
Bousfield localization of the level-wise model structure
\cite[Def.\,3.3]{H-Spectra}.

Just as for the category ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}$ of simplicial $S^1$-spectra,
there isn't a symmetric monoidal category structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$
which lifts the smash product $\wedge$ in ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$.  One remedy is to
use a category of symmetric $T$-spectra ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T^{\Sigma}(B)$.  The
construction of this category is given in \cite[Def.\,7.7]{H-Spectra},
\cite{Jardine}.  By \cite[Thm.\,9.1]{H-Spectra}, there is a zig-zag of
Quillen equivalences from ${\mathrm{Spt}}^{\Sigma}_T(B)$ to ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$, so ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$
is equivalent to the homotopy category of ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T^{\Sigma}(B)$ as
well.  The category ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ therefore is a symmetric monoidal,
triangulated category, where the shift functor is given by
$[1] = S^{1,0}\wedge -$.

In addition to the category of $T$-spectra, we will find it convenient
to work with the category of $({\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1)$ bi-spectra, see
\cite{Jardine, Nordfjordeid}.

\begin{definition} 
  An $S^1$-spectrum over the base scheme $B$ is a sequence of spaces
  $X_n \in {\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$ equipped with structure maps
  $\sigma_n : S^1 \wedge X_n \to X_{n+1}$.  A map of $S^1$-spectra
  $f : X \to Y$ is a sequence of maps $f_n :X_n \to Y_n$ which is
  compatible with the structure maps.  The collection of $S^1$-spectra
  with compatible maps between them forms a category ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B)$.
  Similar to the construction in definition \ref{T-spectra}, the
  stable model structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B)$ is the left Bousfield
  localization of the level model structure on ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B)$ with
  respect to the motivic model structure on ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$ at the stable
  equivalences, cf.~\cite[Def.\,3.3]{H-Spectra}.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition} 
  In the projective model structure on ${\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B)$, the space ${\mathbb{G}}_m$
  pointed at $1$ is not cofibrant.  We abuse notation, and write
  ${\mathbb{G}}_m$ for a cofibrant replacement of ${\mathbb{G}}_m$.  A $({\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1)$
  bi-spectrum over $B$ is a ${\mathbb{G}}_m$-spectrum of $S^1$-spectra.  More
  concretely, a $({\mathbb{G}}_m,S^1)$ bi-spectrum $E$ is a bi-graded family
  of spaces $E_{m,n}$ with bonding maps
  $\sigma_{m,n} : S^1 \wedge E_{m,n} \to E_{m,n+1}$ and
  $\gamma_{m,n} : {\mathbb{G}}_m \wedge E_{m,n} \to E_{m+1,n}$ which are
  compatible, meaning that the following diagram commutes.

There are evidently left Quillen functors
$\Sigma^{\infty}_{S^1} : {\mathrm{Spc}}_*(B) \to {\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B)$ and
$\Sigma^{\infty}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m} : {\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}(B) \to {\mathrm{Spt}}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1}(B)$.
Additionally, the category ${\mathrm{Spt}}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1}(B)$ equipped with the stable model
structure is Quillen equivalent to ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$.

\begin{definition} 
  To any spectrum of simplicial sets $E \in {\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1}$ we may
  associate the constant $S^1$-spectrum $cE$ over $B$ with value $E$.
  That is, $cE$ is the sequence of spaces $cE_n$ with the evident
  bonding maps.  For a simplicial spectrum $E$, we also write $cE$ for
  the $({\mathbb{G}}_m,S^1)$ bi-spectrum $\Sigma^{\infty}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m} cE$.  This
  defines a left Quillen functor $c : {\mathrm{Spt}}_{S^1} \to {\mathrm{Spt}}_{{\mathbb{G}}_m, S^1}(B)$ with
  right adjoint given by evaluation at $B$.  Compare with \cite[Lemma
  6.5]{Levine}.
\end{definition}



\subsection{Base change of stable model categories}

\begin{definition} 
  Let $f : C \to B$ be a map of base schemes.  Pull-back along $f$
  determines a functor $f^{-1} : {\mathrm{Sm}}/B \to {\mathrm{Sm}}/C$, which induces
  Quillen adjunctions
  $(f^*, f_*) : {\mathrm{Spc}}^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}_*(B) \to {\mathrm{Spc}}^{{\mathbb{A}}^1}_*(C)$ and
  $(f^*, f_*) : {\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B) \to {\mathrm{Spt}}_T(C)$.  See e.g.,
  \cite[\S5]{Morel-Con} for more details.

  Let $Q$ (resp.~$R$) denote the cofibrant (resp.~fibrant) replacement
  functor in ${\mathrm{Spt}}_T(B)$.  The derived functors ${\mathbb{L}} f^*$ and
  ${\mathbb{R}} f_*$ are given by the formulas ${\mathbb{L}} f^* = f^* Q$ and
  ${\mathbb{R}} f_* = f_* R$.
\end{definition}

\end{theorem-prop}

\begin{proposition} 
  Let $B$ be a base scheme equipped with a map ${\operatorname{Spec}}({\mathbb{C}}) \to B$.
  Then ${\mathbb{L}} c : {\mathcal{SH}} \to {\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ is faithful.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  For symmetric spectra $X$ and $Y$, the map
  ${\mathbb{L}} c : {\mathcal{SH}}(X,Y) \to {\mathcal{SH}}({\mathbb{C}})(cX,cY)$ factors through
  ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)(cX, cY)$ by proposition \ref{const_comm}.  Hence
  ${\mathbb{L}} c : {\mathcal{SH}}(X,Y) \to {\mathcal{SH}}(B)(cX,cY)$ is injective by theorem
  \ref{levine_comparison}.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary} 
  Write $W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$ for the ring of Witt vectors of ${\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}$ and $K$
  for the fraction field of $W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$ \cite[II \S6]{Serre}.  Then
  ${\mathbb{L}} c : \pi_n^s \to \pi_{n,0}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}))$ is an injection, as we
  have maps $W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}) \to K \to {\mathbb{C}}$.
\end{corollary}





\section{Motivic cohomology}

Spitzweck has constructed a spectrum $H{\mathbb{Z}}$ in ${\mathrm{Spt}}^{\Sigma}_T(B)$ which
represents Levine's motivic cohomology $H_{mot}^i(X,n)$ --- see
\cite{LevineLocalization} --- when $B$ is the Zariski spectrum of a
Dedekind domain.  Spitzweck establishes enough nice properties of
$H{\mathbb{Z}}$ for us to construct the MASS over general base schemes, and
establish comparisons between the MASS over a Hensel local ring and
its residue field.

\subsection{Integral motivic cohomology}

\begin{definition} 
  Over the base scheme ${\operatorname{Spec}}({\mathbb{Z}})$, the spectrum
  $H{\mathbb{Z}}_{{\operatorname{Spec}}({\mathbb{Z}})}$ is defined in \cite[Def.\,4.27]{Spitzweck}.
  For a general base scheme $B$, we define $H{\mathbb{Z}}_B$ to be
  $f^* H{\mathbb{Z}}_{{\operatorname{Spec}}({\mathbb{Z}})}$ where $f : B \to {\operatorname{Spec}}({\mathbb{Z}})$ is the
  unique map.
\end{definition}






Let $B = {\operatorname{Spec}}(D)$ for $D$ a Dedekind domain.  For $X \in {\mathrm{Sm}}/B$,
there is a canonical isomorphism
${\mathcal{SH}}(B)(\Sigma^{\infty}X_+, \Sigma^{i, n}H{\mathbb{Z}}) \cong H^i_{mot}(X,n)$,
where $H^i_{mot}$ denotes Levine's motivic cohomology defined using
Bloch's cycle complex \cite[Cor.\,7.19]{Spitzweck}.  The isomorphism
is functorial with respect to maps in ${\mathrm{Sm}}/B$.  Additionally, if
$i : \{x\} \to B$ is the inclusion of a closed point with residue
field $k(x)$, there is a commutative diagram.

If the residue field $k(x)$ has positive characteristic, there is a
canonical isomorphism of ring spectra
${\mathbb{L}} i^* H{\mathbb{Z}}_B \cong H{\mathbb{Z}}_{k(x)}$ \cite[Thm.\,9.16]{Spitzweck}.

\begin{proposition} 
  If $f : C \to B$ is a smooth map of base schemes, then
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* H{\mathbb{Z}}_B \cong H{\mathbb{Z}}_C$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  Since $f$ is smooth, ${\mathbb{L}} f^* = f^*$, see \cite[p.\,44]{Morel-Con}.
  It is straightforward to see that $f^{*}H{\mathbb{Z}}_B \cong H{\mathbb{Z}}_C$, so
  the result follows.
\end{proof}




\subsection{Motivic cohomology with coefficients ${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$}

For a prime $\ell$, write $H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ for the cofiber of the map
$\ell\cdot: H{\mathbb{Z}} \to H{\mathbb{Z}}$ in ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$.  The spectrum $H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$
represents motivic cohomology with ${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ coefficients.  For a
smooth scheme $X$ over $B$, we write $H^{*,*}(X;{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell)$ for the
motivic cohomology of $X$ with ${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ coefficients.  The mod
$\ell$ Steenrod algebra over $B$ is the bi-graded algebra
${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(B) = {\mathcal{SH}}(B)(H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell, H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell)$.  The dual mod $\ell$
Steenrod algebra over $B$ is the Hopf algebroid
${\mathcal{A}}_{**}(B) = \pi_{**}(H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell \wedge H {\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$).  When $B$
is the spectrum of a ring $R$, we write ${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(R)$ for the
Steenrod algebra instead of ${\mathcal{A}}^{**}({\operatorname{Spec}}(R))$.  We use the same
convention for the dual Steenrod algebra and motivic cohomology.

Let $B={\operatorname{Spec}}(D)$ be the spectrum of a Dedekind domain $D$ in which
$\ell$ is invertible.  Spitzweck shows in
\cite[Thm.\,11.24]{Spitzweck} that the dual Steenrod algebra with
${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ coefficients ${\mathcal{A}}_{**}(D)$ has the expected structure as
a Hopf algebroid, as given in \cite[Thm.\,5.5]{HKOst}.

\begin{definition} 
  Let $D$ be a Dedekind domain, and let $C$ denote the set of
  sequences $(\epsilon_0, r_1, \epsilon_1, r_2, \ldots)$ with
  $\epsilon_i \in \{0,1\}$, $r_i \geq 0$, and only finitely many
  non-zero terms.  The elements
  $\tau_i \in {\mathcal{A}}_{2\ell^i-1,\ell^i-1}(D)$ and
  $\xi_i \in {\mathcal{A}}_{2\ell^r-2,\ell^r-1}(D)$ are constructed in
  \cite[Cor.\,11.23]{Spitzweck}.  For any sequence
  $I = (\epsilon_0, r_1, \epsilon_1, r_2, \ldots)$ in $C$, write
  $\omega(I)$ for the element $\tau_0^{\epsilon_0}\xi_1^{r_1}\cdots$
  and $(p(I),q(I))$ for the bi-degree of the operation $\omega(I)$.
\end{definition}

We record Spitzweck's calculation of the dual Steenrod algebra
\cite[Thm.\,11.24]{Spitzweck} and the Steenrod algebra \cite[Remark
11.25]{Spitzweck} in the following propositions.

\begin{proposition}
\label{dual_steenrod_algebra} 
Let $D$ be a Dedekind domain.  As an $H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$-module, there is a
weak equivalence
$\bigvee_{I\in B} \Sigma^{p(I),q(I)} H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell \to H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell\wedge
H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$.
The map is given by $\omega(I)$ on the factor
$\Sigma^{p(I),q(I)} H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$.
\end{proposition}

\begin{remark}
\label{tau_xi_image} 
Let $D$ be a Dedekind domain in which $\ell$ is invertible, and
consider the map $f : {\mathbb{Z}}[1/\ell] \to D$.  A key observation in the
proof of \cite[Thm.\,11.24]{Spitzweck} is that the map
${\mathbb{L}} f^*:{\mathcal{A}}_{**}({\mathbb{Z}}[1/\ell])\to{\mathcal{A}}_{**}(D)$ satisfies
${\mathbb{L}} f^* \tau_i=\tau_i$ and ${\mathbb{L}} f^* \xi_i=\xi_i$ for all $i$.  For
a map $ j: D \to \widetilde{D}$ of Dedekind domains in which $\ell$ is
invertible, it follows that ${\mathbb{L}} j^* \tau_i = \tau_i$ and
${\mathbb{L}} j^* \xi_i = \xi_i$ for all $i$.
\end{remark}

\begin{proposition}
\label{steenrod_algebra} 
Let $D$ be a Dedekind domain in which $\ell$ is invertible.  The
Steenrod algebra over $D$ is isomorphic to the dual of
${\mathcal{A}}_{**}(D)$, i.e.,
${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(D) \cong {\operatorname{Hom}}({\mathcal{A}}_{**}(D),H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell_{**}(D))$.
\end{proposition}






\section{Motivic Adams spectral sequence}
\label{section:MASS} 
The motivic Adams spectral sequence over a base scheme $B$ may be
defined using the appropriate notion of an Adams resolution, just as
it is done classically \cite{Adams}, \cite{Ravenel}.  We recount the
definition and establish some basic properties of the MASS under base
change.  We follow \cite[\S3]{DI} for the definition of the
(cohomological) motivic Adams spectral sequence.  See also
\cite[\S6]{HKO}.

Let $p\neq 2$ and $\ell$ be fixed primes, $p\neq \ell$.  We will be
interested in the specific case of the MASS over a field and over a
discrete valuation ring (DVR) with residue field of characteristic
$p$.  We write $H$ for the spectrum $H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ over the base scheme
$B$ and $H^{**}(B)$ for the motivic cohomology of $B$ with ${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$
coefficients.  The spectrum $H$ is a ring spectrum and is cellular in
the sense of \cite{DI-Cell} by \cite[Cor.\,11.4]{Spitzweck}.



\subsection{Construction of the mod $\ell$ MASS}

\begin{definition} 
  Consider $X \in {\mathrm{Spt}}^{\Sigma}_T(B)$, and let $\overline{H}$ denote the
  spectrum in the cofibration sequence
  $\overline{H} \to {\mathbbm{1}} \to H \to \Sigma \overline{H}$.  The
  standard $H$-Adams resolution of $X$ is the tower of cofibration
  sequences $X_{f+1} \to X_f \to W_f$ given by
  $X_f = \overline{H}^{\wedge f} \wedge X$ and $W_f = E \wedge X_f$.
  Compare with \cite[\S15]{Adams}.

\begin{definition} 
  A collection of indices
  $\{ (p_{\alpha}, q_{\alpha}) \in {\mathbb{Z}}^2 { \, \vert \, }\alpha \in A\}$ is said
  to be motivically finite if for any $\alpha\in A$ there are only
  finitely many $\beta \in A$ for which $p_{\alpha} \geq p_{\beta}$
  and $2q_{\alpha}-p_{\alpha} \geq 2q_{\beta}-p_{\beta}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[$H^{**}$-MASS] 
  Let $X \in {\mathrm{Spt}}^{\Sigma}_{T}(B)$.  An $H^{**}$-Adams resolution of $X$ is
  a tower of cofibration sequences $X_{f+1} \to X_f \to W_f$ in
  ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ of the following form.  Each spectrum $W_f$ has a
  description
  $W_f \cong \vee_{\alpha} \Sigma^{p_{\alpha},q_{\alpha}} H$ where the
  set of indices $\{(p_{\alpha},q_{\alpha})\}$ is motivically finite,
  and the induced map $H^{**}W_f \to H^{**} X_f$ is a surjection.
prevtext:
If the residue field $k(x)$ has positive characteristic, there is a
canonical isomorphism of ring spectra
${\mathbb{L}} i^* H{\mathbb{Z}}_B \cong H{\mathbb{Z}}_{k(x)}$ \cite[Thm.\,9.16]{Spitzweck}.

\begin{proposition} 
  If $f : C \to B$ is a smooth map of base schemes, then
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* H{\mathbb{Z}}_B \cong H{\mathbb{Z}}_C$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  Since $f$ is smooth, ${\mathbb{L}} f^* = f^*$, see \cite[p.\,44]{Morel-Con}.
  It is straightforward to see that $f^{*}H{\mathbb{Z}}_B \cong H{\mathbb{Z}}_C$, so
  the result follows.
\end{proof}




\subsection{Motivic cohomology with coefficients ${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$}

For a prime $\ell$, write $H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ for the cofiber of the map
$\ell\cdot: H{\mathbb{Z}} \to H{\mathbb{Z}}$ in ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$.  The spectrum $H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$
represents motivic cohomology with ${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ coefficients.  For a
smooth scheme $X$ over $B$, we write $H^{*,*}(X;{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell)$ for the
motivic cohomology of $X$ with ${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ coefficients.  The mod
$\ell$ Steenrod algebra over $B$ is the bi-graded algebra
${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(B) = {\mathcal{SH}}(B)(H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell, H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell)$.  The dual mod $\ell$
Steenrod algebra over $B$ is the Hopf algebroid
${\mathcal{A}}_{**}(B) = \pi_{**}(H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell \wedge H {\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$).  When $B$
is the spectrum of a ring $R$, we write ${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(R)$ for the
Steenrod algebra instead of ${\mathcal{A}}^{**}({\operatorname{Spec}}(R))$.  We use the same
convention for the dual Steenrod algebra and motivic cohomology.

Let $B={\operatorname{Spec}}(D)$ be the spectrum of a Dedekind domain $D$ in which
$\ell$ is invertible.  Spitzweck shows in
\cite[Thm.\,11.24]{Spitzweck} that the dual Steenrod algebra with
${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ coefficients ${\mathcal{A}}_{**}(D)$ has the expected structure as
a Hopf algebroid, as given in \cite[Thm.\,5.5]{HKOst}.

\begin{definition} 
  Let $D$ be a Dedekind domain, and let $C$ denote the set of
  sequences $(\epsilon_0, r_1, \epsilon_1, r_2, \ldots)$ with
  $\epsilon_i \in \{0,1\}$, $r_i \geq 0$, and only finitely many
  non-zero terms.  The elements
  $\tau_i \in {\mathcal{A}}_{2\ell^i-1,\ell^i-1}(D)$ and
  $\xi_i \in {\mathcal{A}}_{2\ell^r-2,\ell^r-1}(D)$ are constructed in
  \cite[Cor.\,11.23]{Spitzweck}.  For any sequence
  $I = (\epsilon_0, r_1, \epsilon_1, r_2, \ldots)$ in $C$, write
  $\omega(I)$ for the element $\tau_0^{\epsilon_0}\xi_1^{r_1}\cdots$
  and $(p(I),q(I))$ for the bi-degree of the operation $\omega(I)$.
\end{definition}

We record Spitzweck's calculation of the dual Steenrod algebra
\cite[Thm.\,11.24]{Spitzweck} and the Steenrod algebra \cite[Remark
11.25]{Spitzweck} in the following propositions.

\begin{proposition}
\label{dual_steenrod_algebra} 
Let $D$ be a Dedekind domain.  As an $H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$-module, there is a
weak equivalence
$\bigvee_{I\in B} \Sigma^{p(I),q(I)} H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell \to H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell\wedge
H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$.
The map is given by $\omega(I)$ on the factor
$\Sigma^{p(I),q(I)} H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$.
\end{proposition}

\begin{remark}
\label{tau_xi_image} 
Let $D$ be a Dedekind domain in which $\ell$ is invertible, and
consider the map $f : {\mathbb{Z}}[1/\ell] \to D$.  A key observation in the
proof of \cite[Thm.\,11.24]{Spitzweck} is that the map
${\mathbb{L}} f^*:{\mathcal{A}}_{**}({\mathbb{Z}}[1/\ell])\to{\mathcal{A}}_{**}(D)$ satisfies
${\mathbb{L}} f^* \tau_i=\tau_i$ and ${\mathbb{L}} f^* \xi_i=\xi_i$ for all $i$.  For
a map $ j: D \to \widetilde{D}$ of Dedekind domains in which $\ell$ is
invertible, it follows that ${\mathbb{L}} j^* \tau_i = \tau_i$ and
${\mathbb{L}} j^* \xi_i = \xi_i$ for all $i$.
\end{remark}

\begin{proposition}
\label{steenrod_algebra} 
Let $D$ be a Dedekind domain in which $\ell$ is invertible.  The
Steenrod algebra over $D$ is isomorphic to the dual of
${\mathcal{A}}_{**}(D)$, i.e.,
${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(D) \cong {\operatorname{Hom}}({\mathcal{A}}_{**}(D),H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell_{**}(D))$.
\end{proposition}






\section{Motivic Adams spectral sequence}
\label{section:MASS} 
The motivic Adams spectral sequence over a base scheme $B$ may be
defined using the appropriate notion of an Adams resolution, just as
it is done classically \cite{Adams}, \cite{Ravenel}.  We recount the
definition and establish some basic properties of the MASS under base
change.  We follow \cite[\S3]{DI} for the definition of the
(cohomological) motivic Adams spectral sequence.  See also
\cite[\S6]{HKO}.

Let $p\neq 2$ and $\ell$ be fixed primes, $p\neq \ell$.  We will be
interested in the specific case of the MASS over a field and over a
discrete valuation ring (DVR) with residue field of characteristic
$p$.  We write $H$ for the spectrum $H{\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ over the base scheme
$B$ and $H^{**}(B)$ for the motivic cohomology of $B$ with ${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$
coefficients.  The spectrum $H$ is a ring spectrum and is cellular in
the sense of \cite{DI-Cell} by \cite[Cor.\,11.4]{Spitzweck}.



\subsection{Construction of the mod $\ell$ MASS}

\begin{definition} 
  Consider $X \in {\mathrm{Spt}}^{\Sigma}_T(B)$, and let $\overline{H}$ denote the
  spectrum in the cofibration sequence
  $\overline{H} \to {\mathbbm{1}} \to H \to \Sigma \overline{H}$.  The
  standard $H$-Adams resolution of $X$ is the tower of cofibration
  sequences $X_{f+1} \to X_f \to W_f$ given by
  $X_f = \overline{H}^{\wedge f} \wedge X$ and $W_f = E \wedge X_f$.
  Compare with \cite[\S15]{Adams}.

The $E_1$ term of the MASS is $E_1^{f,(s,w)} = \pi_{s,w}W_f$.  The
index $f$ is called the Adams filtration, $s$ is the stem, and $w$ is
the motivic weight.

\end{definition}

\begin{definition} 
  Let $X \in {\mathrm{Spt}}^{\Sigma}_T(B)$ and consider an Adams resolution
  $\{X_f, W_f\}$ of $X$.  The Adams filtration of $\pi_{**}X$ is given
  by $F_i\pi_{**}X = {\operatorname{im}}(\pi_{**}X_i \to \pi_{**}X)$.
\end{definition}






\begin{proposition} 
  Let ${\mathfrak{S}}$ denote the category of spectral sequences in the
  category of Abelian groups.  The associated spectral sequence to the
  standard $H$-Adams resolution defines a functor
  $MASS : {\mathcal{SH}}(B) \to {\mathfrak{S}}$.  Furthermore, the motivic Adams spectral
  sequence is natural with respect to base change.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof} 
  The construction of the standard $H$-Adams resolution is functorial.
  Given $X \to X'$ we get induced maps of $H$-Adams resolutions
  $\{ X_f, W_f \} \to \{X_f', W_f'\}$.  As $\pi_{**}(-)$ is a
  triangulated functor, we get an induced map of the associated exact
  couples, and hence of spectral sequences $MASS(X) \to MASS(X')$.

  Let $f:C \to B$ be a map of base schemes.  The claim is that there
  is a natural transformation between $MASS : {\mathcal{SH}}(B) \to {\mathfrak{S}}$ and
  $MASS \circ {\mathbb{L}} f^* : {\mathcal{SH}}(B) \to {\mathcal{SH}}(C) \to {\mathfrak{S}}$.  Let
  $X\in {\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ and let $\{X_f, W_f \}$ be the standard $H_B$-Adams
  resolution of $X$ in ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$.  We may as well assume $X$ is
  cofibrant, so $QX = X$ where $Q$ is the cofibrant replacement
  functor.  Let $\{X_f', W_f'\}$ denote the standard $H_C$-resolution
  of ${\mathbb{L}} f^*X = f^*X$.  Observe that
  $\{f^*X_f , f^*W_f\} = \{X_f',W_f'\}$, since $f^* {\mathbbm{1}} = {\mathbbm{1}}$ and
  $f^* H_B = H_C$.  We therefore have a map
  $\{{\mathbb{L}} f^* X_f, {\mathbb{L}} f^* W_f \} \to \{ X_f',W_f'\}$.  Applying
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* : {\mathcal{SH}}(B)({\mathbbm{1}}^{s,w},-) \to {\mathcal{SH}}(C)({\mathbbm{1}}^{s,w}, {\mathbb{L}} f^*
  -)$
  to $\{X_f, W_f\}$ gives a map of exact couples, and therefore a map
  $\Phi_X : MASS_B(X) \to MASS_C({\mathbb{L}} f^* X)$.  It is straightforward
  to verify that $\Phi$ determines a natural transformation.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary} 
  For a map of base schemes $f : C \to B$, there is a map of motivic
  Adams spectral sequences $\Phi : MASS_B({\mathbbm{1}}) \to MASS_C({\mathbbm{1}})$.
  The map $\Phi$ is furthermore compatible with the induced map
  $\pi_{**}({\mathbbm{1}}_B) \to \pi_{**}({\mathbbm{1}}_C)$.
\end{corollary}

  Suppose $X \in {\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ satisfies the hypotheses of proposition
  \ref{is_resolution}.  The MASS for $X$ has $E_2$-page given by

\begin{definition} 
  Consider a base scheme $B={\operatorname{Spec}}(D)$ for a Dedekind domain $D$.  Let
  ${\operatorname{Ext}}(D)$ denote the tri-graded group
  ${\operatorname{Ext}}_{{\mathcal{A}}^{**}(B)}(H^{**}(B), H^{**}(B))$.
\end{definition}

\begin{corollary} 
  If $X$ and $X'$ are in ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ which satisfy the hypotheses of
  proposition \ref{is_resolution}, and $X \to X'$ induces an
  isomorphism $H^{**} X' \to H^{**}X$, then the induced map
  $MASS(X) \to MASS(X')$ is an isomorphism of spectral sequences from
  the $E_2$-page onward.
\end{corollary}

\begin{corollary}
  \label{mass_iso} 
  Let $f : C \to B$ be a map of base schemes.  Suppose
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* : H^{**}(B) \to H^{**}(C)$,
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* : {\mathcal{A}}^{**}(B) \to {\mathcal{A}}^{**}(C)$, and
  $ {\mathbb{L}} f^* : H^{**}X \to H^{**} ({\mathbb{L}} f^* X)$ are all isomorphisms.
  Then $MASS_B(X) \to MASS_C({\mathbb{L}} f^* X)$ is an isomorphism of
  spectral sequences from the $E_2$ page onward.
\end{corollary}




\subsection{Convergence of MASS}
\begin{proposition}
  \label{convergence}
  Let $B={\operatorname{Spec}}(k)$ be the Zariski spectrum of a field $k$ with
  characteristic $p \neq \ell$.  For $X \in {\mathcal{SH}}(B)$, the motivic Adams
  spectral sequence converges
  $E_2^{f,(s,w)} \Rightarrow \pi_{s,w}X{}^{{\kern -.5pt}\wedge}_{\ell}$ under the following
  conditions: $k$ has finite mod $\ell$ cohomological dimension, $X$
  is cellular and of finite type in the sense of \cite[\S2]{HKO},
  i.e., $H^{**}X$ has a set of generators which is motivically finite
  and $H^{**}X$ is free over $H^{**}(B)$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  The argument given in \cite{HKO} carries over to the positive
  characteristic case from the work of \cite{HKOst}.  See
  \cite[Thm.\,3.1]{LowDimFields} for the analogous argument for the
  motivic Adams-Novikov spectral sequence.
\end{proof}

\begin{remark} 
  The connectivity theorem of Morel is needed to identify what the
  MASS converges to.  It was pointed out by Asok, Hoyois, Drew at the
  2015 USC summer school on $K$-theory that the proof of the
  connectivity theorem for perfect fields has a gap.  (More precisely,
  the published proof of \cite[Lem.\,3.3.9]{Mor03} requires
  characteristic zero).  Our calculations for finite fields are
  conditional upon a valid proof of Morel's connectivity theorem for
  finite fields.  However, in \cite[Lemma 1.15]{Morel12}, it is
  claimed that a version of Gabber's presentation lemma holds for
  finite fields, and that the connectivity theorem therefore holds.
  Should the reader be unsettled by this, we will show that our
  calculations over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$ at least compute
  $\pi_{**} (\widetilde{{\mathbb{F}}}_q){{}^{{\kern -.5pt}\wedge}_2}$ where $\widetilde{{\mathbb{F}}}_q$
  is the union of all field extensions ${\mathbb{F}}_{q^i}$ over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$ with
  $i$ odd.
\end{remark}





































\section{The stable stems $\pi_{n,0}$ over ${\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}$} 
Let $W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$ denote the ring of Witt vectors of ${\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}$, and let
$K$ denote the field of fractions of $W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$.  Consider the maps
${\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p} \xleftarrow{\pi} W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}) \xrightarrow{j} \overline{K}$.  The
previous sections have set us up with enough machinery to compare the
motivic Adams spectral sequences at a prime $\ell \neq p$ over the
associated base schemes ${\operatorname{Spec}}({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$, ${\operatorname{Spec}}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}))$, and
${\operatorname{Spec}}(\overline{K})$.  We will often write the ring instead of the
Zariski spectrum of the ring in our notation.

\begin{proposition}
  \label{fpbar_iso}
  The map $\pi: W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}) \to {\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}$ induces an isomorphism of rings
  ${\mathbb{L}} \pi^* : H^{**}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})) \to H^{**}({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$, and
  ${\mathbb{L}} \pi^* : {\mathcal{A}}^{**}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})) \to {\mathcal{A}}^{**}({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  The spectrum $H$ represents Levine's motivic cohomology with
  ${\mathbb{Z}}/\ell$ coefficients naturally, and base change induces an
  isomorphism
  $H^i(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}), {\mathbb{Z}}/\ell(n)) \to H^i({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}, {\mathbb{Z}}/\ell(n))$ by the
  rigidity theorem \cite[Thm.\,1.2(3)]{Geisser}.

  From the description of $H\wedge H$ as an $H$-module in proposition
  \ref{dual_steenrod_algebra} over $W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$, we see that the map
  ${\mathcal{A}}_{**}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})) \to {\mathcal{A}}_{**}({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$ will be an
  isomorphism if ${\mathbb{L}} \pi^* \tau_i = \tau_i$ and
  ${\mathbb{L}} \pi^* \xi_i = \xi_i$ for all $i$.  This follows from remark
  \ref{tau_xi_image}.  Now as the Steenrod algebra is the dual of
  ${\mathcal{A}}_{**}$ over fields and Dedekind domains, it follows that
  ${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}))\xrightarrow{\cong}{\mathcal{A}}^{**}({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$.
\end{proof}

It is easily checked that $W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$ has the cardinality of the
continuum by the construction in \cite[II \S 6]{Serre}.  Hence the
cardinality of $\overline{K}$ is also that of the continuum.  The
classification of algebraically closed fields yields an isomorphism
$\iota : \overline{K} \to {\mathbb{C}}$.

\begin{proposition}
  \label{kbar_iso} 
  The map $j: W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}) \to \overline{K}$ induces isomorphisms of
  graded rings ${\mathbb{L}} j^* : H^{**}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})) \to H^{**}(\overline{K})$
  and ${\mathbb{L}} j^* : {\mathcal{A}}^{**}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})) \to {\mathcal{A}}^{**}(\overline{K})$.
  Furthermore, the maps
  ${\mathbb{L}} (\iota \circ j)^* : H^{**}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}))\to H^{**}({\mathbb{C}})$ and
  ${\mathbb{L}} (\iota\circ j)^* : {\mathcal{A}}^{**}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})) \to {\mathcal{A}}^{**}({\mathbb{C}})$
  are isomorphisms.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  The localization sequence in motivic cohomology
  \cite[\S1.2]{Geisser-Handbook} for the inclusion
  ${\operatorname{Spec}}({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}) \to {\operatorname{Spec}}(W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}))$ is as follows.

The $E_1$ term of the MASS is $E_1^{f,(s,w)} = \pi_{s,w}W_f$.  The
index $f$ is called the Adams filtration, $s$ is the stem, and $w$ is
the motivic weight.

\end{definition}

\begin{definition} 
  Let $X \in {\mathrm{Spt}}^{\Sigma}_T(B)$ and consider an Adams resolution
  $\{X_f, W_f\}$ of $X$.  The Adams filtration of $\pi_{**}X$ is given
  by $F_i\pi_{**}X = {\operatorname{im}}(\pi_{**}X_i \to \pi_{**}X)$.
\end{definition}






\begin{proposition} 
  Let ${\mathfrak{S}}$ denote the category of spectral sequences in the
  category of Abelian groups.  The associated spectral sequence to the
  standard $H$-Adams resolution defines a functor
  $MASS : {\mathcal{SH}}(B) \to {\mathfrak{S}}$.  Furthermore, the motivic Adams spectral
  sequence is natural with respect to base change.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof} 
  The construction of the standard $H$-Adams resolution is functorial.
  Given $X \to X'$ we get induced maps of $H$-Adams resolutions
  $\{ X_f, W_f \} \to \{X_f', W_f'\}$.  As $\pi_{**}(-)$ is a
  triangulated functor, we get an induced map of the associated exact
  couples, and hence of spectral sequences $MASS(X) \to MASS(X')$.

  Let $f:C \to B$ be a map of base schemes.  The claim is that there
  is a natural transformation between $MASS : {\mathcal{SH}}(B) \to {\mathfrak{S}}$ and
  $MASS \circ {\mathbb{L}} f^* : {\mathcal{SH}}(B) \to {\mathcal{SH}}(C) \to {\mathfrak{S}}$.  Let
  $X\in {\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ and let $\{X_f, W_f \}$ be the standard $H_B$-Adams
  resolution of $X$ in ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$.  We may as well assume $X$ is
  cofibrant, so $QX = X$ where $Q$ is the cofibrant replacement
  functor.  Let $\{X_f', W_f'\}$ denote the standard $H_C$-resolution
  of ${\mathbb{L}} f^*X = f^*X$.  Observe that
  $\{f^*X_f , f^*W_f\} = \{X_f',W_f'\}$, since $f^* {\mathbbm{1}} = {\mathbbm{1}}$ and
  $f^* H_B = H_C$.  We therefore have a map
  $\{{\mathbb{L}} f^* X_f, {\mathbb{L}} f^* W_f \} \to \{ X_f',W_f'\}$.  Applying
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* : {\mathcal{SH}}(B)({\mathbbm{1}}^{s,w},-) \to {\mathcal{SH}}(C)({\mathbbm{1}}^{s,w}, {\mathbb{L}} f^*
  -)$
  to $\{X_f, W_f\}$ gives a map of exact couples, and therefore a map
  $\Phi_X : MASS_B(X) \to MASS_C({\mathbb{L}} f^* X)$.  It is straightforward
  to verify that $\Phi$ determines a natural transformation.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary} 
  For a map of base schemes $f : C \to B$, there is a map of motivic
  Adams spectral sequences $\Phi : MASS_B({\mathbbm{1}}) \to MASS_C({\mathbbm{1}})$.
  The map $\Phi$ is furthermore compatible with the induced map
  $\pi_{**}({\mathbbm{1}}_B) \to \pi_{**}({\mathbbm{1}}_C)$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proposition} 
  Suppose $X \in {\mathcal{SH}}(B)$ satisfies the hypotheses of proposition
  \ref{is_resolution}.  The MASS for $X$ has $E_2$-page given by

of ${\mathcal{SH}}(k)^{\ell}$ for algebraically closed fields of characteristic 0
\cite{ROst}, so the result follows.
\end{proof}

\begin{proposition} 
  Let $B$ be the Zariski spectrum of ${\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}$, $W({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$, or ${\mathbb{C}}$.
  Let $\{X_f, W_f\}$ be an Adams resolution for ${\mathbbm{1}}$ in ${\mathcal{SH}}(B)$,
  and define $\hat{{\mathbbm{1}}} = {\mathbbm{1}}/{\operatorname{holim}} X_f$.  The MASS for ${\mathbbm{1}}$
  converges to $\pi_{**} \hat{{\mathbbm{1}}}$, filtered by the Adams
  filtration.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
  The Adams filtration of $\pi_{**}\hat{{\mathbbm{1}}}$ is exhaustive and
  Hausdorff by construction. The vanishing line in the MASS guarantees
  that the filtration is complete, hence convergence follows.
\end{proof}

\section{MASS for finite fields ${\mathbb{F}}_q$}

We now analyze the 2-complete stable stems
$\hat{\pi}_{**}({\mathbb{F}}_q) = (\pi_{**}{\mathbbm{1}}_{{\mathbb{F}}_q}){{}^{{\kern -.5pt}\wedge}_2}$ when $q$
and $2$ are relatively prime.  The results of the previous section
allow us to identify the $n$th classical 2-complete stable stem
$\hat{\pi}_n^s = (\pi_n^s){{}^{{\kern -.5pt}\wedge}_2}$ as a summand of
$\hat{\pi}_{n,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$.  Using this, we are able to analyze the
MASS for ${\mathbb{F}}_q$ in a range.  For the remainder of this section, let
$H$ denote the spectrum representing motivic cohomology with ${\mathbb{Z}}/2$
coefficients. 


\subsection{The $E_2$-page of MASS over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$}

Recall that the motivic cohomology of a field $F$ has the description
$H^{**}(F) \cong K^M_*(F)/2[\tau]$ where $K^M_n(F)/2$ is in degree
$(n,n)$, and $\tau$ is in degree $(0,1)$.  As
$K^M_1({\mathbb{F}}_q) = {\mathbb{F}}_q^{\times}$ and $K^M_n({\mathbb{F}}_q) = 0 $ for
$n \geq 2$, we conclude $H^{**}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \cong {\mathbb{F}}_2[\tau, u]/(u^2)$
where $u$ is the nontrivial element of
$H^{1,1}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \cong {\mathbb{F}}_q^{\times}/2$.

nexttext:
The differential $d_1$ satisfies the Leibniz rule, so it suffices to
identify the differential on irreducible elements.  We describe these
differentials in the following proposition.

\begin{proposition} 
  In the $\rho$-BSS for ${\mathbb{F}}_q$ with $q \equiv 3 \bmod 4$, every
  irreducible element $x$ of ${\operatorname{Ext}}({\mathbb{C}})$ in stem $s\leq 19$ other
  than $\tau$ has $d_1 x = 0$.  Also, $d_1 \tau = \rho h_0$ and
  $d_1 ([\tau g]) = \rho h_2 e_0$.  Here, $[\tau g]$ is the
  irreducible element of ${\operatorname{Ext}}({\mathbb{C}})$ in stem $20$, weight $11$, and
  filtration $4$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  The differential $d_1$ vanishes on the classes $h_0$, $h_1$, $c_0$,
  $Ph_1$, $d_0$, $Pc_0$, $e_0$, $P^2h_1$ since there is nothing for
  them to hit.  The remaining differentials were identified by
  computer calculation in \cite{Fu-Wilson}. 
\end{proof}






\begin{example} 
  Since $d_1 h_1 =0$, we conclude $d_1 \tau h_1 = \rho h_0 h_1 = 0$,
  as $h_0h_1$ vanishes in ${\operatorname{Ext}}({\mathbb{C}})$.  Hence there is a class
  $[\tau h_1] \in {\operatorname{Ext}}^{1,(1,0)}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$ which is irreducible.
\end{example}





With this analysis of the $\rho$-BSS for ${\mathbb{F}}_q$ with
$q \equiv 3 \bmod 4$, one can determine the structure of
${\operatorname{Ext}}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$ as a graded Abelian group up to stem $20$.  In
\cite{DI-Real}, Dugger and Isaksen are additionally able to determine
the product structure of ${\operatorname{Ext}}({\mathbb{R}})$ from the $\rho$-BSS.  Some of
their techniques apply over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$.  We instead use a computer
calculation of ${\operatorname{Ext}}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$ which includes the product structure in
our analysis of the stable stems.

\subsection{Stable stems over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$}

We now begin an analysis of the differentials in the MASS to identify
the two-complete stable stems over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$. To assist the reader with
the computations presented below, figure \ref{fig:1mod4} and figure
\ref{fig:3mod4} display $E_2$ page charts of the MASS over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$.
Further charts can be found in \cite{Fu-Wilson}.

\begin{proposition} 
  Let $q=p^n$ where $p$ is a prime different from $2$.  The group
  $\hat{\pi}_n^s$ is a summand of $\hat{\pi}_{n,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$ for
  $n\geq 0$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  The map ${\mathbb{L}} c : \pi_n^s \to \pi_{n,0}{\mathbbm{1}}_{{\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p}}$ factors
  through $\pi_{n,0}{\mathbbm{1}}_{{\mathbb{F}}_q}$.  Passing to the $2$-completion,
  theorem \ref{ellcomp_iso} implies the composition
  $\hat{\pi}_n^s \to \hat{\pi}_{n,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to
  \hat{\pi}_{n,0}({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_p})$ is an isomorphism.  Hence the result.
\end{proof}

For small values of $n\geq 0$ we have $\hat{\pi}_{n,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \cong
\hat{\pi}_n^s \oplus \hat{\pi}_{n+1}^s$.  This pattern fails when $n =
19$ and $q \equiv 5 \bmod 8$.

\begin{proposition}
  \label{5mod8} 
  When $q \equiv 5 \bmod 8$ and $0 \leq n \leq 18$, there is an
  isomorphism
  $\hat{\pi}_{n,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \cong \hat{\pi}_n^s \oplus
  \hat{\pi}_{n+1}^s$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  The irreducible elements of ${\operatorname{Ext}}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$ in this range are
  tabulated in proposition \ref{irred_1mod4}.  All differentials $d_r$
  for $r\geq 2$ vanish on $h_0,h_1,h_3,c_0,Ph_1, d_0, Pc_0, P^2h_1$
  since there is nothing for them to hit.  As
  $\hat{\pi}_{3,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$ must contain $\hat{\pi}_3^s \cong {\mathbb{Z}}/8$
  as a summand, we conclude $d_2 (h_2) = 0$.  As $Ph_2$ equals the
  Massey product $\langle h_3, h_0^4, h_2\rangle$ the differential
  $d_2 (Ph_2) = 0$, since $d_2 (h_2) = 0$. Similarly, as
  $P^2h_2 = \langle h_3, h_0^4, h_2\rangle$ we calculate
  $d_2 P^2h_2 = 0$.

  The differential $d_2 (h_4) = h_0 h_3^2$ is deduced from the
  comparison $MASS({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to MASS({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_q})\cong MASS({\mathbb{C}})$.  This
  comparison also shows $d_3 (h_0h_4)$ is non-zero. In order to have
  $\hat{\pi}_{14}^s$ as a summand of $\hat{\pi}_{14,0}$, we must have
  $d_3(h_0h_4) = h_0d_0$. Similarly, $d_2 (e_0) = h_1^2 d_0$,
  $d_2 (f_0) = h_0^2 e_0$.  Note that $d_4 (h_0^4 h_4) = 0$ since
  there is nothing for it to hit.  The elements in weight $0$ are all
  of the form $\tau^i x$ or $u\tau^{i-1}x$ where $x$ is not a multiple
  of $\tau$ and of weight $i$.  The differentials of the elements in
  weight $0$ are now readily identified by using the Leibniz rule.
  Since $\hat{\pi}_n^s$ is a summand of $\hat{\pi}_{n,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$ for
  all $n$, we see that there are no hidden extensions for $n \leq 18$,
  so the result follows.


\end{proof}

\begin{proposition}
  \label{19and20} 
  When $q \equiv 5 \bmod 8$,
  $\hat{\pi}_{19,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \cong ({\mathbb{Z}}/8 \oplus {\mathbb{Z}}/2) \oplus
  {\mathbb{Z}}/4$ and $\hat{\pi}_{20,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \cong {\mathbb{Z}}/8 \oplus {\mathbb{Z}}/2$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  We must have $d_2 [\tau g] = 0$ for dimension reasons. Since
  $[\tau g]$ has weight 11, the class $\tau^{11} [\tau g] $ is in
  $E^{4,(20,0)}$.  Using proposition \ref{tau-differentials}, we
  calculate
  $d_2 \tau^{11} [\tau g] = u \tau^{10} h_0^2 [\tau g] \neq 0$.  This
  resolves all of the differentials in the 19- and 20-stem, and the
  calculation of the 19-stem follows.  As
  $\hat{\pi}_{20}^s \cong {\mathbb{Z}}/8$ must be a summand of
  $\hat{\pi}_{20,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$, we conclude there is a hidden extension
  from $u \tau^{11} h_2^2 h_4 = u \tau^{11} h_3^3$ to
  $\tau^{12}h_2 e_0$.  The calculation of the 20-stem now follows.
\end{proof} 

\begin{remark} 
  Note that over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$ with $q \equiv 5 \bmod 8$, the map
  ${\mathbb{L}} c \{g\}$ is detected by $u \tau^{11} h_3^3$ which is in Adams
  filtration 3, and not 4.  But over ${\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_q}$,
  ${\mathbb{L}} c\{g\}$ is in Adams filtration 4.
\end{remark}

\begin{proposition} 
  When $q \equiv 1 \bmod 8$ and $0 \leq n \leq 20$, there is an
  isomorphism
  $\hat{\pi}_{n,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \cong \hat{\pi}_n^s \oplus
  \hat{\pi}_{n+1}^s$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  The same argument as in proposition \ref{5mod8} goes through in this
  case as well.  The difference is that when $q \equiv 1 \bmod 8$,
  $d_2 \tau = 0$ by proposition \ref{tau-differentials}, and therefore
  $d_2 \tau^{11}[\tau g] = 0$.  This determines all of the
  differentials needed to compute up to the 20-stem.  We note that
  there are no possible hidden extensions in the 19- or 20-stem in this
  case. The result then follows.
\end{proof} 


\begin{proposition}
  \label{3mod4} 
  When $q \equiv 3 \bmod 4$ and $0\leq n \leq 18$, there is an
  isomorphism
  $\hat{\pi}_{n,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \cong \hat{\pi}_n^s \oplus
  \hat{\pi}_{n+1}^s$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  The differentials $d_r$ for $r\geq 2$ vanish on the following
  generators for degree reasons: $[\rho \tau]$, $\rho$, $h_0$, $h_1$,
  $h_3$, $[\tau h_2^2]$, $[\tau c_0]$, $[\tau Ph_1]$, $d_0$,
  $[\tau P c_0]$, $[\tau P^2h_1]$.  Since $\hat{\pi}_1^s \cong {\mathbb{Z}}/2$
  is a summand of $\hat{\pi}_{1,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$, we must have
  $d_r [\tau h_1] = 0$ for all $r\geq 2$.  Since
  $\hat{\pi}_3^s \cong {\mathbb{Z}}/8$ is a summand of
  $\hat{\pi}_{3,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$, we must have $d_2 (h_2) = 0$.  Just as in
  proposition \ref{5mod8}, we conclude $d_2 (h_4) = h_0 h_3^2$,
  $d_2 (e_0) = h_1^2 d_0$, and $d_2 (f_0) = h_0^2 e_0$ by comparison
  to $MASS({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_q})$. Also, we determine $d_r [\tau c_1] = 0$ for
  $r\geq 2$ by comparing with $MASS({\overline{{\mathbb{F}}}_q})$, as the class
  $[\tau c_1]$ must be a permanent cycle.

  The one exceptional case is $d_3 (h_0h_4)$.  Here we must have
  $d_3 (h_0h_4) = h_0d_0 + \rho h_1 d_0$ in order for
  $\hat{\pi}_{14}^s = {\mathbb{Z}}/2\oplus {\mathbb{Z}}/2$ to be a summand of
  $\hat{\pi}_{14,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$.  

  The elements in weight $0$ are all of the form $([\tau^2])^i x$ or
  $[\rho\tau][\tau^2]^{i-1}x$ where $x$ is not a multiple of $\tau^2$
  and weight $2i$, or of the form $\rho[\tau^2]^i x$ if $x$ is not a
  multiple of $\tau^2$ and of weight $2i+1$.  The differentials of the
  elements in weight $0$ are now readily identified by using the
  Leibniz rule.  Since $\lambda(q) = \nu_2(q^2-1) \geq 3$, we have
  $d_2 \tau^2 = 0$.  This is sufficient to ensure that for elements
  $x$ in stem $n \leq 18$ there are no non-trivial differentials of
  the form $d_r [\tau^2]^i x = \rho\tau^{2i-1} h_0^r x$ when
  $[\tau^2]^i x$ has weight~$0$.
\end{proof}






\begin{remark} 
  It is unclear whether $d_2[\tau^2 g] = [\rho \tau g]$ or
  $d_2 [\tau^2 g] = 0$.  This is all that obstructs the identification
  of the stems $\hat{\pi}_{19,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$ and
  $\hat{\pi}_{20,0}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$.
\end{remark}


\subsection{Base change for finite fields}

\begin{proposition}
  \label{odd-base-change} 
  Let $q = p^n$ where $p$ is an odd prime.  For a field extension
  $f : {\mathbb{F}}_q \to {\mathbb{F}}_{q^i}$ with $i$ odd, the induced map
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* : H^{**}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to H^{**}({\mathbb{F}}_{q^i})$ and
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* : {\mathcal{A}}^{**}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to {\mathcal{A}}^{**}({\mathbb{F}}_{q^i})$ are
  isomorphisms.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  The claim follows by checking on \'etale cohomology.  The map on
  cohomology is determined by
  $H^1_{et}({\mathbb{F}}_q;\mu_2) \to H^1_{et}({\mathbb{F}}_{q^i};\mu_2)$ which is
  just the induced map ${\mathbb{F}}_q^{\times}/2 \to {\mathbb{F}}_{q^i}^{\times}/2$.
  So long as $i$ is odd, this map is an isomorphism.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary} 
  For $q = p^n$ with $p$ an odd prime, the induced map
  $MASS({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to MASS({\mathbb{F}}_{q^i})$ is an isomorphism of spectral
  sequences whenever $i$ is odd.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proposition} 
  Let $q = p^n$ with $p$ an odd prime.  Let $\widetilde{{\mathbb{F}}}_q$
  denote the union of the field extensions ${\mathbb{F}}_{q^i}$ over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$
  with $i$ odd.  The field extension
  $f : {\mathbb{F}}_q \to \widetilde{{\mathbb{F}}}_q$ induces isomorphisms
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* : H^{**}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to H^{**}(\widetilde{{\mathbb{F}}}_q)$ and
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* : {\mathcal{A}}^{**}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to {\mathcal{A}}^{**}(\widetilde{{\mathbb{F}}}_q)$.
  Hence the map $MASS({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to MASS(\widetilde{{\mathbb{F}}}_q)$ is an
  isomorphism of spectral sequences.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  This follows by a colimit argument, using proposition
  \ref{odd-base-change}.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary} 
  Assuming Morel's connectivity theorem holds for ${\mathbb{F}}_q$, for any
  integers $i$ and $j$, there is an isomorphism
  $\hat{\pi}_{i,j}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \cong \hat{\pi}_{i,j}(\widetilde{{\mathbb{F}}}_q)$.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proposition} 
  \label{even_extension}
  Let $q= p^n$ with $p$ an odd prime.  For a field extension
  $f : {\mathbb{F}}_q \to {\mathbb{F}}_{q^i}$ with $i$ even, the map
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* : H^{1,*}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to H^{1, *}({\mathbb{F}}_{q^i})$ is the trivial
  map.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof} 
  The map is determined by
  ${\mathbb{L}} f^* : H^{1,1}({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to \ H^{1,1}({\mathbb{F}}_{q^i})$ which is just
  the map ${\mathbb{F}}_q^{\times}/2 \to {\mathbb{F}}_{q^i}^{\times}/2$.  However, any
  non-square $x \in {\mathbb{F}}_q^{\times}$, will be a square in
  ${\mathbb{F}}_{q^i}^{\times}$ when $i$ is even.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}
  Let $q= p^n$ with $p$ an odd prime.  For a field extension
  $f : {\mathbb{F}}_q \to {\mathbb{F}}_{q^i}$ with $i$ even, the induced map
  $MASS({\mathbb{F}}_q) \to {\mathbb{F}}_{q^i}$ kills the class $u$, (respectively
  $\rho$ and $[\rho \tau]$) and all of their multiples at the $E_2$
  page.
\end{corollary}

\begin{proof}
  The induced map of cobar complexes is determined from proposition
  \ref{even_extension}, which shows the classes $u$ (respectively
  $\rho$ and $[\rho \tau]$) are killed under base change.
\end{proof}


\section{Implementation of motivic Ext group calculations}
\label{section:implementation}

The computer calculations used in this paper were done with the
program available from \cite{Fu-Wilson} at
\url{https://github.com/glenwilson/MassProg}. The program is written
in python, and calculates ${\operatorname{Ext}}(F)$ for the fields ${\mathbb{C}}$, ${\mathbb{R}}$, and
${\mathbb{F}}_q$ by producing a minimal resolution of $H^{**}(F)$ by
${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(F)$ modules in a range. With this complex in hand, the
program then produces its dual and calculates cohomology in each
degree. 

To calculate a free resolution of $H^{**}(F)$ of
${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(F)$-modules, we first need the program to efficiently
perform calculations in ${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(F)$. The mod 2 motivic Steenrod
algebra is generated by the squaring operations ${\operatorname{Sq}}^i$ and the cup
products $\alpha \cup - $ for $\alpha \in H^{**}(F)$. These generators
satisfy Adem relations, which are given in \cite[Thm.\,5.1]{HKOst}, 
\cite[Thm.\,10.2]{MR2031198}. 
Additionally, one needs the commutation relations
${\operatorname{Sq}}^{2i}\tau = \tau {\operatorname{Sq}}^{2i} + \tau \rho {\operatorname{Sq}}^{2i-1}$ for $i >0$ and
${\operatorname{Sq}}^{2i+1}\tau = \tau {\operatorname{Sq}}^{2i+1} + \rho {\operatorname{Sq}}^{2i} + \rho^2 {\operatorname{Sq}}^{2i-1}$
for $i\geq 0$ which are obtained from the Cartan formula. With these
relations, the program can calculate the canonical form of any element
of ${\mathcal{A}}^{**}$, that is, as a sum of monomials $\alpha\cdot {\operatorname{Sq}}^I$
where $\alpha \in H^{**}(F)$ and $I$ is an admissible sequence. 

With the algebra of ${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(F)$ available to the program, it then
proceeds to calculate a minimal resolution of $H^{**}(F)$ by
${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(F)$ modules. This is where a great deal of computational
effort is spent. To clarify what a minimal resolution is in practice,
let $\prec$ denote the order on ${\mathbb{Z}}\times{\mathbb{Z}}$ given by
$(m_1,n_1)\prec(m_2,n_2)$ if and only if $m_1 + n_1 < m_2 + n_2$, or
$m_1 + n_1 = m_2 + n_2$ and $n_1 < n_2$. The reader is encouraged to
compare this definition with the definition in \cite[Def.\
9.3]{McCleary}, and consult \cite{BB3} for detailed calculations of a
minimal resolution for the Adams spectral sequence of topology.

\begin{definition}
  A resolution of $H^{**}(F)$ by ${\mathcal{A}}^{**}(F)$ modules
  $H^{**}(F) \leftarrow P^{\bullet}$ is a minimal resolution if the
  following conditions are satisfied.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Each module $P^i$ has an ordered basis $h_i(j)$ such that if
  $j\leq k$ then $\deg h_i(j) \prec \deg h_i(k)$.
    \item ${\operatorname{im}}(h_i(j)) \notin {\operatorname{im}}(\langle h_i(j) { \, \vert \, } j < k \rangle)$
    \item $\deg h_i(j)$ is minimal with respect to degree in the order
  $\prec$ over all elements in
  $P^{i-1} \setminus {\operatorname{im}}(\langle h_i(j) { \, \vert \, } j < k\rangle)$.
\end{enumerate} 
\end{definition}

The computer program calculates the first $n$ maps and modules in a
minimal resolution up to bi-degree $(2n, n)$. With this, it then
calculates the dual of the resolution by applying the functor
${\operatorname{Hom}}_{{\mathcal{A}}^{**}(F)}(-,H^{**}(F))$ to the resolution
$P^{\bullet}$. With the cochain complex
${\operatorname{Hom}}_{{\mathcal{A}}^{**}(F)}(P^{\bullet}, H^{**}(F))$ in hand, the program
calculates cohomology in each degree, i.e.,
${\operatorname{Ext}}^{f,(s+f,w)}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$. 

As the program calculates an explicit resolution of $H^{**}(F)$, the
products of elements in ${\operatorname{Ext}}(F)$ can be obtained from the composition
product, cf.\ \cite[Thm.\ 9.5]{McCleary}.


\section{Charts}
\label{section:charts}

The weight 0 part of the $E_2$ page of the mod 2 MASS over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$ is
depicted in figures \ref{fig:1mod4}, \ref{fig:3mod4} according to the
case $q \equiv 1 \bmod 4$ or $q \equiv 3 \bmod 4$. The weight 0 part
of the $E_{\infty}$ page of the mod 2 MASS over ${\mathbb{F}}_q$ can be found
in figures \ref{fig:1mod8}, \ref{fig:5mod8}, \ref{fig:3mod4-infty}.

In each chart, a circular or square dot in grading $(s, f)$ represents
a generator of the ${\mathbb{F}}_2$ vector space in the graded piece of the
spectral sequence. The square dots are used to indicate that the given
element is divisible by $u$, $\rho$, or $\rho\tau$, depending on the
case. Circular dots denote elements which are not divisible by $u$,
$\rho$, or $\rho\tau$. In the chart \ref{fig:3mod4-infty}, there is an
oval dot which corresponds to the class with representative
$\tau^8 \rho h_1 d_0 \equiv \tau^8 h_0 d_0$, as the class
$\rho h_1 d_0 + h_0 d_0$ is killed.

The labels in the chart correspond to those elements coming from
irreducible elements of ${\operatorname{Ext}}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$. However, most of these
elements must be multiplied by the appropriate power of $\tau$ or
$[\tau^2]$ to land in the weight 0 part of the spectral sequence. We
leave this off in the notation, as the weights of these elements are
listed in tables \ref{table:1mod4} and \ref{table:3mod4}.

We indicate that the product of a given class by $h_0$ with a solid,
vertical line. In the case $q \equiv 3 \bmod 4$, multiplication by
$\rho h_1$ plays an important role, so non-zero products by $\rho h_1$
are indicated by dashed vertical lines. In particular, when
$q \equiv 3 \bmod 4$, multiplication by $2$ in
$\hat{\pi}_{**}({\mathbb{F}}_q)$ is detected by multiplication by
$h_0 + \rho h_1$.  The lines of slope 1 indicate multiplication by
$\tau h_1$ or $[\tau h_1]$ depending on the case.

Dotted lines are used in two separate instances in these charts. The
first use is in figure \ref{fig:5mod8}, where dotted lines indicate
hidden extensions by $h_0$ and $\tau h_1$. The other instance is in
figure \ref{fig:3mod4-infty} to indicate an unknown $d_2$
differential.

Additional charts can be found in \cite{Fu-Wilson}.
